Smith
Robert G. Smith, a senior in the
School of Arts and Sciences, has been
awarded a $1000 post-graduate award
liar one year by the National Collegiate
Athletic Association. Smith who has a
3.2 average and is planning to attend
Harvard Law School, played forward
on Hopkins' 19'64-65 basketball team
and was its captain.
Criteria for the award are a 3.0
seholastic average and exceptional
athletic ability. Smith is one of ten college basketball players in the country
ft0 receive this award. The NCAA also
game out twenty football scholarships
of a similar nature last fall.
An announcement of the award winners will be made tomorrow night at
the NCAA championship basketball
game in Portland, Oregon.

Marchers Demand
Federal Protection
On Sunday, March 14, approximately
30 people participated in a 30-mile
march from Baltimore to Washington
to demand that President Johnson take
action to protect civil-rights demonstrators in Selma, Alabama.
They were students from Johns Hopkins, Morgan College, and several local
high schools, along with civil rights
workers and local people from Cambridge, Maryland. Organizations represented were the Hopkins-Goucher SDS,
Baltimore CORE, SNCC, and the Cambridge Non-Violent Action Committee.
The marchens had three major demands. First, they demanded effective
federal protection of Selma demonstrators, including troops if necessary. secondly, they demanded free, non- discriminatory elections in Missisippi and
Alabama, together with a federal voting
bill which would guarantee the right
to vote to all citizens subject only to
age residence re(iuirements. Finally, the
marchers demanded the arrest of
Sheriff Clark, Colonel Lingo of the Alabama State Police, Governor Wallace,
and all others involved in the violent
dispersal of civil-rights demonstrators
attempting, to march from Selina to
Montgomery Sunday, March 7.
The marchers arrived in front of the
White House at 3:30 P.M., ana attended
the end of a rally in Lafayette Park of
15,000 persons. For art hour the marchens joined about 5,000 .people picketing
in front of the White House for federal
protection of the Selma demonsteatons.

Dr. Chapanis' lecture will be based
on unpublished research into the use
of color names and the agreement
among people in what they mean by
these color names.
In the major study to be reported
upon, a list of 233 color names was
constructed by taking twelve commonly
used color names singly, as compound
names, and in combination with 11
modifiers. For each color name, each of
40 subjects (20 men and 20 women) was
required to search through 1359 color
chips to find the one chip which, in
the subject's opinion, best exemplified
the color name.
Though the findings are not yet complete, it has been noted that most
subjects consider certain color names,
previously thought to be distinctive, as
essentially equivalent. Also, significant
differences have appeared between the
two sexes in their we of color names.
Finally, it appeals that despite the profusion of color names in our vocabulary,
certain regions of color space remain
nameless.
Dr. Chapanis, who received his Ph.D.
from Yale University in 1942 has been
with Hopkins since 1946.

The Big Spring Weekend will be held
on April 9 and 10. The YMCA and the
IFC have combined to present the
Weekend, which this year 'A ill feature
both a jazz concert and a dance.
On Friday night April 9, Duke Eningtion, the famous jazz pianist, will give
a concert in the Baltimore City College
Auditorium. Tickets for the concert will
be •available at the YMCA office za
Leverisig Hall.
Saturday night will feature the dance,
with music supplied by the nationally
known recording and concert group.
Hank Ballard and the Midnightens.
Tickets will be sold by the IFC, the
Student Council, the DSRC and the
YMCA, and will cost 5 per couple. Refreshments will be available, and table
reservations will be arranged through
the IFC. The 5th Regiment Armory is
under consideration as the location far
the dance.
Referring to the combination of
Ellington's concert and the big dance,
IFC President Jon Harlow said. "We
feel sure that Hopkins has never had
a weekend of this magnitude or quality.
JHU finally has a Big Weekend to rival
those notorious weekends at Princeton,
UVA, Randolph-Macon and the other
'swinging' schools."

Booze In Danger!!

The perennial Hopkins drinking problem has once again come to the fore.
Although the school has not as yet made
any rules against drinking in the stands,
a crackdown appeals imminent if students are not on their best behavior.
For the first few games no restrictions have been placed on liquor in the
bleachers. Enforcement of any such decree would be impossible since the field
will not be fenced in until the new
athletic center is all but completed.
Without the fences, entrances to the
field are just too hard to control.
Conduct Checked
Students however, will be under surveillance during this period. Whether
new restrictions are imposed after the

fence goes up probably depends on students' and their dates') behavior iltip
the interim.
The Council contemplated briefly how
to educate the student body to this
grave situation, but reached no final
decision.
Bumper-jumper Muddle
In other business, freshman representative Bill Reinsch cited the need some cif
his constituents felt for a bumperjumper on the road past the new library. This proposal was mumbled ou6
oil existence with Ralph Cann mumbling the strongest protest, "We'll be
running a road course pretty soon, on
a series of speed traps."

If your roommate
says the Bell System helped invent
hi-ti, stereo and talking movies,

don't bet. You'll lose.
In the course of their studies of the nature
of sound, Bell System scientists have been
able to make significant contributions to all
three forms of entertainment.
You might say that it was because the discoveries were there to be discovered by the
first explorers to come down the trail.
When the century was still young, we realized that if the telephone were to come up
to its potential, the nature of sound had to
be much better understood than it was then.
This led to the largest, most comprehensive

study of sound ever undertaken by anyone.
To capture sound for study, Bell Telephone
Laboratories developed the first electronic recorder for phonograph discs. For the first
time, performers recorded into microphones.
Then, in 1925, Bell Labs perfected an electronic system that synchronized sound and
action on movie film. The talkies were born.
To get better sound reproduction, they
started experimenting in 1933 with ways to
separate high and low frequencies to prevent
distortion. The result was a single-groove,

or

multi-channel disc—the basis today's stereophonic industry.
Nevertheless, these contributions were byproducts of the real effort, which was to make
telephone service better. We are proud, of
course, that they helped build and improve
whole industries.
But we're prouder of the sound qualities in
the telephone of today.
If you'd like to do business or engineering
work you're really proud of, we'd like to talk
to you.

Spring Band Concert Elicits
Mixed Review From Critic
By CHRISTOPHER MALLOY
Although it has been a very
acceptable thing to pan and ridicule the concert band, a pan of
this spring's concert is not in order. Last Saturday night's Shriver Hall performance demonstrated a greatly improved band with a
Very musical program in spite of
their few relapsing, and per'Ps characteristic, weaknesses.
The first half was unquestionably the better one, if only because the works were better
sttited to concert band. There is
Much in music that is inappropriate for concert band, and this
concert showed an understandof that discipline much better than the first concert of last
fall. The adaptability of BernBach, and Handel far outshone the second act imports
frotn Ravel and Grofe.
The opening Bach choral
Showed a full realization of the
warmth and mellowness that
Bach affords, but the abortive
hiPped-in-the-tuck phrasing indicates inadequate rehearsal.
Par more satisfying was the
Overture to Candide. The band
executed well what could be a
touchy balance between Broad-

Student Director Conrad D.

A tribute is owed to William

execution of the various marches.
As a close of both halves of the
concert the band showed that
the fine-an-dandy can be musical, and the sis-boom-bah can be
to a good end.

IFC-Saw
The corralling of seventy percent of the freshman
class and the frictions and fractions inevitably involved,
made this year's rush season a little rough going. The
administration, either through incognizance, or by reason
of some mellowing, found this year's routiness within
tolerance; the way in which the IFC tethered its own
members has not been as rosy.
In the IFC Judicial Committee trial, reported by
the News-Leiter two weeks ago—rather difficult information to get one's hands on—a fraternity was convicted of a rush violation involving eleven freshmen. The
penalty decided upon was loss of a rush party and a
fine of $350. None of the freshmen involved was
penaltzed.
According to the IFC Constitution, however, no
such penalties are stipulated, nor is there even any provision for imposing them. The case in point is a major
rush violation (more than two rushees involved), and
it is that particular fraternity's first this year. Under the
Constitution the requisite penalty for such a violation
is a "closed house for the following party." No fine is
mentioned. For each rushee involved the constitution
requires they "be forbidden to pledge the fraternity
with which he participated in said violation until the
following rush period."
By levying the fine the IFC exceeded the restrictions
of its constitution; by pardoning the freshmen it used
the argument that since the trial was held after Pledge
Saturday no rushee was involved. Some sections of the
Constitution are apparently more sacred than others.
But even this is dubious since the trial was held after
rush, because of a deal between the IFC president and
a freshman involved. The freshman testified only when
he was assured his friends would not be affected. The
president agreed despite th fact that he is nowhere empowered to do this and, anyhow: "Rushees shall be
required to testify at trials and investigations held by
the Council. Their failure to testify shall, at the discretion of the Council, result in their being blacklisted
for one year." (Article 5, section 2).
The rectitude of the entire decision is questionable. What is much more questionable is the attitude
of the IFC toward its own constitution. Failure to abide
by it certainly doesn't do the fraternity system any
good. Fuzzy penalties invite each fraternity to define
its own rush rules. The IFC Constitution ought to he
either observed or amended.

In various analyses into the nature of students,
!several magazines of late have endeavored to discover
the essence of studentship. But students remain an
enigma to surveys and statistics, and emerge comprehensible only from within. Oblivious of these external
observers, here sits the real little Caesar on the crumbling steps of Homewood House aerating his soul at the
end of a string.

JHU Prof. Edits
New AnchorBible
By RON SHEA
"The work now being produced in the field of biblical
studies is more interesting and
informative than ever before,"
states William F. Albright, Professor Emeritus of Semitic Languages. One example of this new
approach to the study of the
Bible, with which Dr. Albright
is intimately connected, is now
finally nearing its culmination.
The first public manifestation of
these researches was the publication of two volumes—Genesis
and The Epistles of James Peter
And Jude—of the Anchor Bible.
"Recent events," Dr. Albright
said, "in the historical study of
the Middle East have been revolutionary. Almost nothing was
known in this field outside of the
Bible until the nineteenth century, and most of the outstanding discoveries have been in the
last forty or fifty years."
Of these discoveries the archeological finds of the Dead Sea
Scrolls and the Ras Shamra
texts have fostered the greatest
advances. "Now," he continued,
"we have all sorts of parallels
with which to study the Bible.
After all, one must explain the
Bible as what it is,—a religious
and historical classic without
equal in the world—not as an
existentialist treatise. In this respect, it can only be understood
In the same manner that one
understands any other serious
record."
"I cannot emphasize too greatly," said Professor Albright,
"that these books are not the
expressions of any religious organization. The venture is in no
way related to Catholic, Protestant, or Jewish organizations and
is supported by a completely
secular commercial press."
"Authors for the volume," added the Professor Emeritus. "are
selected from all denominations
—Catholic, Jewish, Protestant,
and even a few agnostics, including E. A. Speiser, author of
the Genesis study. Our only
criterion for writer selection has
been competence and scholarship. In this we have had remarkable
luck.
Outstanding

people have taken hold of the
idea and are working on various
books, and all, except for a few
not yet definitely assigned, the
38 volumes are coming along
nicely."
"The Anchor Bible," said Dr.
Albright, one of the two general editors of the series, "was
originally suggested to me in
1956 by Jason Epstein, who was
at that time editor of the
Doubleday Anchor Paperbacks. I
advised him to invite one of my
former students, Dr. David Noel
Freedman, to serve as the other
general editor."

Of Kibrarirs
By HOCK

By DON BACHELLER
A Hopkins Student, once my friend,
While seeking out a place to learn;
The library he did descend,
Prepared the midnight oil to burn.
Through stately portals he did pass,
Like warrior in days of old,
Those castle doors of steel and glass,
Behung with purple and with gold.
He placed his books on table fine,
And opened them so tenderly.
He read of emp'rors Byzantine,
And studied Freshman chemistry.
He studied on a chair so soft,
At table rich of stately grain,
But soon he raised his eyes aloft,
For he did feel a hunger pain.
This warrior from a distant land,
At Hopkins was both new and green,
He took his dime within his hand.
And went in quest of food machine.
But in this building wide and deep,
With marble wall and stately door,
They do not any sust'nance keep,
For fear of wrappers on the floor.
He searched and searched that fateful night,
From level A to level D,
And morning found him still and white,
He fell of hunger, verily.
And so this humble warrior fell,
While looking for a food machine,
And though we hear the mourning bell,
The Boor forever shall be clean.
And from his spirit high above,
A wailing voice comes from afar,
Place on my grave a snow white dove,
And don't forget a Hershey Bar.

on-campus training during your junior year ... six additional weeks at camp

Marchers Demand
Federal Protection
On Sunday, March 14, approximately
30 people participated in a 30-mile
march from Baltimore to Washington
to demand that President Johnson take
action to protect civil-rights demonstrators in Selma, Alabama.
They were students from Johns Hopkins, Morgan College, and several local
high schools, along with civil rights
workers and local people from Cambridge, Maryland. Organizations represented were the Hopkins-Goucher SDS,
Baltimore CORE, SNCC, and the Cambridge Non-Violent Action Committee.
The marchens had three major demands. First, they demanded effective
federal protection of Selma demonstrators, including troops if necessary. secondly, they demanded free, non- discriminatory elections in Missisippi and
Alabama, together with a federal voting
bill which would guarantee the right
to vote to all citizens subject only to
age residence re(iuirements. Finally, the
marchers demanded the arrest of
Sheriff Clark, Colonel Lingo of the Alabama State Police, Governor Wallace,
and all others involved in the violent
dispersal of civil-rights demonstrators
attempting, to march from Selina to
Montgomery Sunday, March 7.
The marchers arrived in front of the
White House at 3:30 P.M., ana attended
the end of a rally in Lafayette Park of
15,000 persons. For art hour the marchens joined about 5,000 .people picketing
in front of the White House for federal
protection of the Selma demonsteatons.

Dr. Chapanis' lecture will be based
on unpublished research into the use
of color names and the agreement
among people in what they mean by
these color names.
In the major study to be reported
upon, a list of 233 color names was
constructed by taking twelve commonly
used color names singly, as compound
names, and in combination with 11
modifiers. For each color name, each of
40 subjects (20 men and 20 women) was
required to search through 1359 color
chips to find the one chip which, in
the subject's opinion, best exemplified
the color name.
Though the findings are not yet complete, it has been noted that most
subjects consider certain color names,
previously thought to be distinctive, as
essentially equivalent. Also, significant
differences have appeared between the
two sexes in their we of color names.
Finally, it appeals that despite the profusion of color names in our vocabulary,
certain regions of color space remain
nameless.
Dr. Chapanis, who received his Ph.D.
from Yale University in 1942 has been
with Hopkins since 1946.

athletic center is all but completed.

field are just too hard to control.

grave situation, but reached no final
decision.

If your roommate
says the Bell System helped invent
hi-ti, stereo and talking movies,

don't bet. You'll lose.
In the course of their studies of the nature
of sound, Bell System scientists have been
able to make significant contributions to all
three forms of entertainment.
You might say that it was because the discoveries were there to be discovered by the
first explorers to come down the trail.
When the century was still young, we realized that if the telephone were to come up
to its potential, the nature of sound had to
be much better understood than it was then.
This led to the largest, most comprehensive

study of sound ever undertaken by anyone.
To capture sound for study, Bell Telephone
Laboratories developed the first electronic recorder for phonograph discs. For the first
time, performers recorded into microphones.
Then, in 1925, Bell Labs perfected an electronic system that synchronized sound and
action on movie film. The talkies were born.
To get better sound reproduction, they
started experimenting in 1933 with ways to
separate high and low frequencies to prevent
distortion. The result was a single-groove,

or

multi-channel disc—the basis today's stereophonic industry.
Nevertheless, these contributions were byproducts of the real effort, which was to make
telephone service better. We are proud, of
course, that they helped build and improve
whole industries.
But we're prouder of the sound qualities in
the telephone of today.
If you'd like to do business or engineering
work you're really proud of, we'd like to talk
to you.

IFC-Saw
The corralling of seventy percent of the freshman
class and the frictions and fractions inevitably involved,
made this year's rush season a little rough going. The
administration, either through incognizance, or by reason
of some mellowing, found this year's routiness within
tolerance; the way in which the IFC tethered its own
members has not been as rosy.
In the IFC Judicial Committee trial, reported by
the News-Leiter two weeks ago—rather difficult information to get one's hands on—a fraternity was convicted of a rush violation involving eleven freshmen. The
penalty decided upon was loss of a rush party and a
fine of $350. None of the freshmen involved was
penaltzed.
According to the IFC Constitution, however, no
such penalties are stipulated, nor is there even any provision for imposing them. The case in point is a major
rush violation (more than two rushees involved), and
it is that particular fraternity's first this year. Under the
Constitution the requisite penalty for such a violation
is a "closed house for the following party." No fine is
mentioned. For each rushee involved the constitution
requires they "be forbidden to pledge the fraternity
with which he participated in said violation until the
following rush period."
By levying the fine the IFC exceeded the restrictions
of its constitution; by pardoning the freshmen it used
the argument that since the trial was held after Pledge
Saturday no rushee was involved. Some sections of the
Constitution are apparently more sacred than others.
But even this is dubious since the trial was held after
rush, because of a deal between the IFC president and
a freshman involved. The freshman testified only when
he was assured his friends would not be affected. The
president agreed despite th fact that he is nowhere empowered to do this and, anyhow: "Rushees shall be
required to testify at trials and investigations held by
the Council. Their failure to testify shall, at the discretion of the Council, result in their being blacklisted
for one year." (Article 5, section 2).

JHU Prof. Edits
New AnchorBible
By RON SHEA
"The work now being produced in the field of biblical
studies is more interesting and
informative than ever before,"
states William F. Albright, Professor Emeritus of Semitic Languages. One example of this new
approach to the study of the
Bible, with which Dr. Albright
is intimately connected, is now
finally nearing its culmination.
The first public manifestation of
these researches was the publication of two volumes—Genesis
and The Epistles of James Peter
And Jude—of the Anchor Bible.
"Recent events," Dr. Albright
said, "in the historical study of
the Middle East have been revolutionary. Almost nothing was
known in this field outside of the
Bible until the nineteenth century, and most of the outstanding discoveries have been in the
last forty or fifty years."
Of these discoveries the archeological finds of the Dead Sea
Scrolls and the Ras Shamra
texts have fostered the greatest
advances. "Now," he continued,
"we have all sorts of parallels
with which to study the Bible.
After all, one must explain the
Bible as what it is,—a religious
and historical classic without
equal in the world—not as an
existentialist treatise. In this respect, it can only be understood
In the same manner that one
understands any other serious
record."
"I cannot emphasize too greatly," said Professor Albright,
"that these books are not the
expressions of any religious organization. The venture is in no
way related to Catholic, Protestant, or Jewish organizations and
is supported by a completely
secular commercial press."
"Authors for the volume," added the Professor Emeritus. "are
selected from all denominations
—Catholic, Jewish, Protestant,
and even a few agnostics, including E. A. Speiser, author of
the Genesis study. Our only
criterion for writer selection has
been competence and scholarship. In this we have had remarkable
luck.
Outstanding

people have taken hold of the
idea and are working on various
books, and all, except for a few
not yet definitely assigned, the
38 volumes are coming along
nicely."
"The Anchor Bible," said Dr.
Albright, one of the two general editors of the series, "was
originally suggested to me in
1956 by Jason Epstein, who was
at that time editor of the
Doubleday Anchor Paperbacks. I
advised him to invite one of my
former students, Dr. David Noel
Freedman, to serve as the other
general editor."

SDS Pushes I
Demonstration

Of Kibrarirs
By HOCK

By DON BACHELLER
A Hopkins Student, once my friend,
While seeking out a place to learn;
The library he did descend,
Prepared the midnight oil to burn.
Through stately portals he did pass,
Like warrior in days of old,
Those castle doors of steel and glass,
Behung with purple and with gold.
He placed his books on table fine,
And opened them so tenderly.
He read of emp'rors Byzantine,
And studied Freshman chemistry.
He studied on a chair so soft,
At table rich of stately grain,
But soon he raised his eyes aloft,
For he did feel a hunger pain.
This warrior from a distant land,
At Hopkins was both new and green,
He took his dime within his hand.
And went in quest of food machine.
But in this building wide and deep,
With marble wall and stately door,
They do not any sust'nance keep,
For fear of wrappers on the floor.
He searched and searched that fateful night,
From level A to level D,
And morning found him still and white,
He fell of hunger, verily.
And so this humble warrior fell,
While looking for a food machine,
And though we hear the mourning bell,
The Boor forever shall be clean.
And from his spirit high above,
A wailing voice comes from afar,
Place on my grave a snow white dove,
And don't forget a Hershey Bar.

Army ROTC during their first two years—will commence with six weeks of
field training this coming Summer, beginning June 14. Then you'll have
on-campus training during your junior year ... six additional weeks at camp
during the following Summer ... and more on-campus training during your
senior year. Even flight training is offered at some schools.

campus life... extra spending money ($40 per month during your junior
and senior school years, and even more during Summer training)... and,
when you graduate, an Army Officer's commission as Second Lieutenant.
Then you'll normally spend two interesting years on active duty, often
abroad with opportunities for travel.

Fusting, Price Head List
Heading the list of middies are
newcomers Gene Fusting and
Marcy Price. Fusting led the
country in scoring last year
while at Washington College.
and Price starred for Baltimore
University. Other Mount Washington midfielders include Ab
Tiedemann, Tom Reilly, Larry
Levitt, Buzzy Krongard, Randy
Walker, Joe Seivold, Dave Cordish, and face-off ace Tom Biddison.
Expected to start at defense
are Gene Reckner, Frank Riggs
and former Hopkins star Phil
Sutley. In the goal for the Wolfpack, as usual, will be Jim Kappler.
"Have Hustle"
"To win this game, we'll have
to excel in our hustle and effort
between the restraining lines,"
declared Scott. "We will play a
ball control game, since they
have as good an offense as anyone."
Stressing that Yale will be
stronger this year, Scott added,
"We were fortunate to beat them
last season. Our ninth goal was
scored with 5% minutes to go.
We played a haphazard game."
Bradford Back
Mac Bradford will head the
Yale attack. He scored five
goals and registered one assist
in last year's contest; over the
summer, he sharpened up by
competing in Long Island's tough
Jones Beach League.
On defense, Chuck Benait,
5'10" 210-lb. football co-captain,
leads the Elis. He was a second
team All-America choice last
year.
Yale is coached by Dick Corrigan, brother of Virginia mentor Gene Corrigan. Assistant
coach of the Bulldogs is Toni
Scott, New York Giants' linebacker.
